fields.label_text:
Silver Gallery:
Coconuts were, from the 15th century, treasured for their healing properties. Silversmiths were frequently called upon to mount coconuts in silver to make tankards, goblets and elaborate covered cups. Drinking from a coconut cup was believed to cure all sorts of ailments such as fever, kidney failure and tapeworm. They were not only restorative. They were also thought to have the added power of being an aphrodisiac!

fields.descriptive_line: Coconut jug of made with coconut and silver, made in Breda, ca. 1620.
fields.physical_description: Coconut mounted in 3 vertical silver straps, on a raised circular foot with silver lining inside bowl, handle cast in the form of a figure, hinged lid with cast finial, the silver chased and engraved.
fields.dimensions: Diameter: 10.60 cm top, Diameter: 9.30 cm foot, Height: 18.20 cm, Length: 14.30 cm
fields.materials_techniques: Coconut and silver, chased and engraved
fields.label:
Silver Gallery:
Coconuts were, from the 15th century, treasured for their healing properties. Silversmiths were frequently called upon to mount coconuts in silver to make tankards, goblets and elaborate covered cups. Drinking from a coconut cup was believed to cure all sorts of ailments such as fever, kidney failure and tapeworm. They were not only restorative. They were also thought to have the added power of being an aphrodisiac! [26/11/2002]
fields.marks:
Inscribed under the foot: viiii VNSEN 8 ENGELS (TS: possibly the weight? )
 Mark W in a shaped shield, unidentified, town mark 3 crosses under a crown in a straight sided shield for Breda.
fields.credit: Given by Dr W. L. Hildburgh
fields.history_note:
Dr WL Hildburgh FSA Gift


Hildburgh's collecting activities were European in scope, but he clearly had a particular fondness for mounted exotica, as had many collectors before him. 
Walter Leo Hildburgh was one of the most dedicated and generous patrons in the history of the V&A. His name is not well-known outside the museum world, but his influence on the shaping of the collections was immense. Born in New York in 1876, he trained as a scientist. Initially his collecting interest was ethnography, but after 1914 he turned to the decorative arts. His tastes were eclectic, but he developed his closest links with the Departments of Metalwork and Sculpture. Encouraged by successive Keepers of Metalwork, he began to accumulate European silver, with the gaps in the existing collections in mind. He travelled widely on collecting expeditions, usually recording when and where he bought something, but not (frustratingly for posterity) from whom. 
Hildburgh's abiding passion was the art of Spain and Portugal, and it is no coincidence that the Museum holds one of the finest collections of Hispanic silver in the world. He also fell into the charming habit of giving the Museum presents at Christmas and on his own birthday.  In some ways he was a shadowy figure, living frugally in a flat surrounded by what he called `the Museum mistakes', and devoting all his resources to collecting, but he is known to have been a keen skater. From 1924 when he offered the first objects to the Museum on loan, to 1956 when the huge  collection was bequeathed, Hildburgh was  part of the Museum landscape. We continue to benefit from his generosity; his will set up a fund for future purchases, administered in the spirit of his earlier acquisitions.
TS: the inside of the jug is later
